posts.author: Kalistez
posts.content:
So I have been spending a bit of time in Alboria over the last couple of weeks, and the gear I have come across so far has been impressive - one of the other players even said the gear you get at higher levels is unbelievable.

So it got me thinking, if we can assume that in a high magic world we are going to reach all of the caps (AB, Abilities, Saves, Dodge AC) what do you look for when building ?

The general consensus is that dex toons are the way to go in high magic worlds, and then things that cant be added (as far as I know) by items.

So to start with I figure we want base AB and saves as high as possible.

Epic Dodge would almost be a given

Then Taunt, for essentially another 6 AB beyond the cap.

Expertise for 5 AC

And possibly SCV

Sword and Board or Dual Wield beats 2 handers or fists, as you want as many items equipped as possible for the properties on them.

I had a play around and came up with the build below, but was curious as to how the rest of you would tackle building for the situation above.

posts.content:
Mmmm ...

If I want a build for a high magic world for pure powerbuilding I would want a dex dual wield kama multi-attribute dependant (M.A.D.) monk build with UMD, evasion and uncanny dodge. Epic dodge is strong too.

10 attack per round build means each point of added damage to the kama rockets the damage upwards, with sky high dex you will be using robes anyway

Maybe like a elf paladin monk rogue or something like that. Undispellable death ward, freedom, plus divine favor and divine might to add damage per hit. Take 20 of paladin pre-epic for maximum AB then go monk/rogue epic levels to grab epic dodge and the monk UBAB 

So like Paladin 26 / Monk 1 / Rogue 13 to take epic prowess and epic weapon focus as bonus feats to allow for as many great dexterity feats as possible 

Or  Paladin 24 / Monk 3 / Rogue 13 for Monk Speed and Deflect Arrows and Epic Dodge with a sky high reflex save

posts.author: Valerfor
posts.content:
You could start with 8 charisma & up your constitution to 12, gaining another 40 hp's.
Divine might isn't worth it in my opinion for this build, besides, you're missing PA & STR 13+ for taking it, unless I'm forgetting something here.
Better move BF pre-epic & get another great DEX there, start with 19 DEX & get back to 46AB.
Str10, Dex19(34), Con10, Int13, Wis14, Cha8, I think, might be better for you.

The AB is very good for a Paladin, cause you can raise it up by 8 points regardless of the weapon's enchantment (as long as you don't go over the +20 cap, that is) & you have Monk's attack progression with the farm implements. Thus, AB should be something like: 46 (base) +6 (dexterity) +10 (enchantment) +8 (Paladin spells) -2 (ITWF) = 68AB with 9 attacks & Monk progression, on a typical +10 high-magic world. Not worth to also attempt flurry, but I assumed perma-haste of course.
 
Nevertheless, this is a good build, Orion, & certainly, high-magic approved.

posts.author: Mick Dagger
posts.content:
I think the question here is what kind of build will shine in a high magic environment.
Self-buffers will not feel any good when everyone can get better than their buffs from items floating around. Mages will struggle when all opponents have items with immunity and resistance to everything they can throw at them. CoT will not benefit from their saves bonus. It counts towards the cap and you get items that let you cap the saves anyway. True seeing will nerf stealth and invisibility.  Immunities will absorb the damage from traps.
+20 AC from dodge, deflection, natural, armor and shield is hard to beat even with a high AB, a capped +20 AB bonus and +6 from a capped attack stat.
A typical scenario in such environments is the "Battle of 20s" where you never beat the high AC, and only are able to land a hit on a natural 20 roll.
In these extreme cases AB doesn't play much of a role anymore. The number of attacks per round, on the other side, determines how many chances you get at rolling that 20.
In borderline cases, having a high innate AC can help you exceed what your enemy is able to hit, and  force him into rolling for 20s to be able to hit you. Expertise can help with that. In those borderline cases it still helps to have a high innate AB as long as it makes you within reach of hitting the enemy.

I will try to explain why many people prefer dexterity builds for this kind of high magic scenario.
In a battle of 20s between a strength build and a dexterity build, both will roll a 20 on 5% of their attempts. The strength build will do some more damage on a hit from the strength bonus. But the bigger the weapon enhancements, the smaller is the relative difference. Sometimes the weapon enhancements are so huge that the players question if taking two feats (WS and EWS) is worth it for only a +6 to damage.
In the battle of 20s Dev crit is useless.  When you hit on your 20 roll you threat a critical hit, but to confirm it you have to roll again and this time there is no auto-hit on 20. So you will never be able to confirm the critical hit.
Dexterity builds have higher AC in general. That matters at least in cases bordering on a battle of 20s.
ED will avoid the first hit in each round. That is far better than only cancelling out an attack per round, since you only roll a 20 in 5% of the cases.
50% concealment helps you avoid being hit 50% of the times, or at least 25% if your enemy has Blind fight. Add that to ED and see how often you actually get hit. All builds can get 50% concealment temporarily if they have access to the Displacement or the Improved invisibility spells. If you get it via UMD on scrolls or from item properties, they are usually easily dispellable. The assassins get the Improved invisibility spell as a class feat and monks get the Empty body feat that gives 50% concealment twice per day.
Dexterity builds have access to the Self concealment feats. 5 feats give you 50% concealment that is undispellable. You need dex 30 before you can start taking it, so it is indeed for dedicated dexterity builds.

My personal opinion is that high magic is one dimensional and ends up being boring. It can feel exciting when you find items with über properties. But if it makes you too powerful, there is little challenge anymore. And when when both you and your enemies have items that protect against everything and AC becomes too high to overcome, there is little left of the game and its challenges.
